title: 113_s1850
content:
The Act titled "Domestic Refugee Resettlement Reform and Modernization Act of 2013" defines key terms like community-based organization, Director, and national resettlement agencies. It also includes an assessment of refugee domestic resettlement programs. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of domestic refugee resettlement programs operated by the Office of Refugee Resettlement. This study will analyze how self-sufficiency is defined, the effectiveness of programs in helping refugees, and the budgetary resources needed to address refugee needs. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the effectiveness of domestic refugee resettlement programs, focusing on self-sufficiency, community-based organizations, and recommended statutory changes. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on domestic refugee resettlement programs, focusing on self-sufficiency, community-based organizations, and recommended statutory changes. A report will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the enactment of this Act. Refugee assistance is addressed in Section 4. The Director will ensure assistance for secondary migrant refugees who meet eligibility requirements. A report on secondary migration will be submitted annually to Congress, detailing states affected and reasons for migration. Amendments to Social Services Funding include considerations for secondary migrant refugees, such as projections on the number and nature of incoming migrants. The Director must issue a proposed rule for a new formula for grants and contracts allocation within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Public comments on the proposed rule must be solicited. The amendments made by this section will be effective on the first day of the fiscal year following the Act's enactment. SEC. 5. RESETTLEMENT DATA. The Director will expand the Office of Refugee Resettlement's data analysis, collection, and sharing activities to track national and State trends on refugees with urgent medical needs, including mental health conditions. Coordination with various organizations will be done to collect information on refugees' health screening data. The Director will collect data on refugee housing needs, including homelessness and risk of homelessness, in partnership with state programs and organizations. Additionally, longitudinal information on refugee self-sufficiency and employment status will be gathered during a 2-year period after their arrival in the United States. The Director will annually update and submit a report to Congress containing data collected on refugee housing needs, self-sufficiency, and employment status in the United States. SEC. 6. GUIDANCE REGARDING REFUGEE PLACEMENT DECISIONS.

The Secretary of State will provide guidance on consultation with local stakeholders for refugee resettlement. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will collect and share best practices on stakeholder consultation with voluntary agencies and State refugee coordinators.

SEC. 7. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act will take effect 90 days after enactment, except for the amendments made by section 4.
